pros: - Opportunities for growth and career advancement : Intel is a large company with many departments and areas of expertise, providing employees with numerous opportunities for growth and career advancement. - Competitive compensation and benefits : Intel offers competitive compensation packages, including salaries, bonuses, and stock options. The company also provides comprehensive benefits packages that include health insurance, retirement plans, and paid time off. - Innovative work environment : Intel is at the forefront of technological innovation, and employees have the opportunity to work on cutting-edge projects and products. - Global presence: Intel has a global presence, with offices and facilities around the world, providing employees with the opportunity to work on international projects and collaborate with colleagues from diverse backgrounds.
cons: - High-pressure work environment : Intel operates in a highly competitive industry, and employees may experience high-pressure work environments with tight deadlines and demanding workloads. - Limited work-life balance : Intel may require employees to work long hours or be available to work outside of regular business hours, which can impact work-life balance. - Frequent restructuring and changes : As a large company, Intel may undergo frequent restructuring and changes, which can lead to uncertainty and job instability for employees. - Slow decision-making processes : Intel is a large organization, and decision-making processes can be slow, which can be frustrating for employees who need to move quickly to meet project deadlines or other business needs.

pros: - Great bonus system; anyone can give anyone else a bonus, with manager permission. - Top-level talent; so many people to learn from. - Flexible work hours; most people aren't concerned about the hours you work, provided you get the work don.e - Opportunity to work different roles; anyone can apply for a gig (2-20 hours a week) in another team, building out their expertise in that area.
cons: - High expectations. The bar is high and exceeding that often is near impossible. Can make life stressful. - Over-management; lots of schemes and initiatives created by a bored middle-management, that take up lots of time with little return more often than not. - Death by meetings; often feels like I spend more time in meetings than it does doing work. Everyone claims that anyone is free to leave when they feel the meeting isn't provided value, but in reality, you're expected to be and participate in them.

review_title: I would give it a shot
pros: This is a technician level position, so it can be a nice foot in the door for someone just out of school or in possession of an associates degree. Military experience is also accepted for this position. The pay is relatively good. The management and people working here are some of the greatest you'll ever encounter. Great benefits and growth opportunities are there if you really want them.
cons: Culture of "need to know" is confusing to people that function best when they understand how everything works. If you can be told to do a thing and repeat it and you aren't compelled to understand things beyond the scope of your position, this is fine, you'll love it. Feed your family and you are good to go. But if you are inquisitive, this job will be tough. Without the bachelors (if you don't have), they won't pay you much attention. You won't get training beyond what they want you to do and it will really confuse you when you interact with other departments. It compartmentalized in a way that makes it impossible for you to put the pieces together, unless you work here for several decades.

job_title: RD Packaging Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Very good experience people there than can transfer they knowledge if they want
cons: Intel is too big to be competitive and maintain the market leadership like 10 years ago. Smaller companies who are more specialized in one or two area are eating Intel's lunch. Currently Intel is involved in multiple categories such as foundry, design and assembly/test which is not on top in any of those. TSMC and Samsung chips are better and OSATs do much better jobs in test/assembly. I believe this eventually leads to more downfall.

review_title: Overll Moving in the Right Direction
pros: The engineers are top-notch and very down-to-earth in my experience. Compa ratios increased last year to become more competitive with the rest of the industry. Good benefits package (well-priced insurance, standard retirement plan, some good benefits when buying things from other companies and some fantastic deals on Intel products). Still at the forefront of processor design and innovation. Management seems to be moving in the right direction. Pat's weekly updates feel a lot more transparent than past CEOs. Lot of long-term development and investment plans that could really pay off - an exciting roadmap. If Pat is to be believed, we are at the bottom of a saddle period now, so we will be riding high again in not too long as R&D is completed and investments pay off.
cons: Currently in a contraction. Management overspent during the COVID semiconductor boom and is paying for it now. Job security is a concern during these times. Management could still work a little bit on transparency and listening to feedback. Product development and timelines in the past few years was atrocious, but a lot of changes were implemented that seem to be getting things back on-track.

job_title: Senior Maintenance Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Safety is very important in the culture. Hard to lose your job. Superviors tend to be people oriented. The use of technology to cover a multiple tools spread over a large area is amazing but need to be refined.
cons: Safety is important but if it slows things down, you are accountable for the time lost. This means you have to find a safe way to accomplishs the task at a faster pace safely. Hiring cheap these days, it is find a way to train new tech to have 20 years of experience in 9 months. The numbers of tech are not increasing with the number of fabs. 1.2 miles from one tool to the next and your are manage to the speed at which you travel from one to the other.

pros: Co-workers are great to work with! GSM, HVM sites, other organizations for the most part have good and solid Managers! Organizations within intel (HVM sites, GSM, sales, etc.) are for the most part excellent to work for and with. Intel is a great company for the most part which I have a vast appreciation for!
cons: Other organizations within intel cater far too much to TD organization which contributes to their weak performances and results thus their limited success. Large # of TD Mgmt. are self-absorbed/arrogant and thus rarely listen and follow direction of others. Difficult to work with for the most part although they do have some good Manager's, but they are far and few in-between.

review_title: Good work-life balance, not so good salary and perks
job_title: Cloud Developer in San Jose, CA
pros: The company does innovative work and usually does not require employee to overwork.
cons: Salaries are not very competitive and benefits/perks are pretty basic. Can you believe that they have vending machines for a bag of chips?? Looks like they really need our quarters to be profitable. Compare that with free lunch at Google... In the SJI building they don't even have coffee, but other buildings do. In the bay area a big chunk of the salary is in stocks, but the stock price has been going down for years, so you end up being paid way less than promised when the stocks vest, and the management doesn't seem to care. They even cut the base salaries lately, equally to almost everyone, with no difference for bad and top performers, which is not giving a good signal.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Good health insurance. Between vacation, floating holidays and personal absence time, time off is better than most companies if you are not exempt.
cons: Used to be a great place to work, now, it is just another big tech company whos employees are just numbers. They have widdled the perks down to nothing saying it is industry standard. If you want to have the best talent, shouldn't you offer more than standard? 401k used to be SERP of 12%, did not have to contribute at all, then it was 10, then 8, then 6 to a 401k match of 5% to now the match is dropped to 2%. Just the tip of many other lost incentives

pros: The only reasons that I'm staying right now is for the healthcare benefits and my team members. Currently looking for other employment.
cons: The work that I do is more administrative than engineering. The training is horrible. Information is difficult to get, systems are out dated, tools are out dated, benefits have been cut or taken away, there are people who have been around for 20+ years and refuse to train new people saying that it's a waste of their time. Intel loves to have meetings... just to have meetings! They don't like to see that there is any down time. Intel expects everyone to do the job of more than one person, so everyone is over worked, exhausted, and brain washed. Toxic.

pros: good work life balance weekends are strictly off from work No unnecessary layoffs
cons: Salary scale is relatively lower and depends on team and their domain. Even if you are a great engineer if you are posted in a team that doesn't generate a lot of revenue you will be paid less Very less benefits apart from salary when compared to other product companies of this stature

review_title: Avoid the Dry-Etch Department! Experience might differ in other departments.
pros: The health benefits are good.
cons: Manamgnet is horrible. Group Leaders are not appropriately trained. Area managers hide behind the group leaders and provide few solutions for their overworked technicians. They will work you to death, and they prevent Grade Level promotions. You can perform all of your job duties and still not advance. It is not a suitable environment for mental health; you will experience a lot of anxiety trying to please management and engineering.

job_title: Application Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: 1. There are some awesome teams - pick carefully though. 2. Women's networking groups 3. Amazing mentoring ("Find an Expert") 4. Some amazing teammates and ability to form human connections with strangers 5. Definite pockets without gender issues, but pick manager carefully. 6. Suggest women work with witi.com for more info on women working at Intel and to hopefully find the right spot.
cons: 1. Some areas have toxic work environment for women - but certainly not all! 2. Intel has only recently begun to fix pay for women (doubling my friend's base salary), but has done nothing to fix the fact that low pay is compounded by: stock options and bonuses based on base pay, and any % raise is based on low pay. This causes a cumulation of lost $$ much higher than simple base salary comparison. 3. Don't go to HR if you have a problem with a toxic work environment. There is a way to search for/interview for other internal jobs without your boss knowing about it. Switch jobs asap if there is a problem. Because it is most probably not about you, and you can't fix a bad situation. 4. Strongly suggest you maximize base pay (due to cumulative impact) during job negotiations. New California laws also require them to be more transparent about pay so that inequities are more visible. Advocate for yourself without expecting fairness. 5. Like many companies, "corporate values" are simply words without substance.

pros: it's a great place to work, with plenty of opportunities to learn. Company perks are great. If you like working in a busy & highly paced working environment, then yeah can give it a try.

review_title: Good community but fundamental issues unaddressed

It is unclear if Intel can engineer its turnaround when there are still too many layers of managers and siloes to work through effectively and, as leadership likes to request, at a "torrid pace"

job_title: System Validation Engineer in Guadalajara, Jalisco
pros: * Salary tends to be higher than average * Nice bonuses * Good medical insurance
cons: * Expect a lot of burnout; the "power on" crunches are particularly severe. * Cutthroat performance evaluation; expect a lot of intrigues and backstabbing over salary raises and/or promotions. * Managers at Guadalajara have never grown a spine to oppose stupid decisions from headquarters. * The 2016 layoffs leaned towards 40-60 year old employees, which prompted employees in the US to sue Intel over age-based discrimination; Intel has been dragging out the lawsuits ever since. In Guadalajara Intel leveraged its clout over the governor of Jalisco back then, Aristoteles Sandoval, to make the state labor ministry have a blind eye over the conditioning of our severance payment to sign a 5-year non-disclosure agreement; we were also vetoed from being re-hired until October 2022... and only because the pandemic employment crisis also hit Intel.

review_title: Great working environment, an all you can eat buffet of engineering
pros: Students get basically the same type of tasks as full-time employees. It will take a few months to prove your worth and get the management to trust you with significant tasks, but once that's done you will be treated as an equal team member. This allows you to learn a whole lot more than in similar jobs in other companies that only give "dirty work" to students. Additionally, as Intel is an international company you will be in touch with coworkers around the globe which is a great opportunity to improve your English. The fact that you are able to work from home offers much-needed flexibility that allows you to balance work and studies.
cons: The job is quite demanding. There is always more work to be done, and there are often meetings in the evening with coworkers around the globe. This means there is very little separation between "work" and "home". You will likely have to work more than the already demanding 2.5 days you are required by the contract to finish all your tasks on time.

review_title: Great benefits - Hyper Corporate Culture - Soul Sucking
pros: Compensation is fair, benefits are comprehensive, amenities are above average.
cons:
Hyper corporate culture and excessive benefits unrelated to compensation spoil the employees. People get basically unlimited time off if they utter a whiff of personal trouble. I was a manager and had folks that extended their earned time off and when I brought this up to HR, they said there is nothing they can do. I had one employee that I inherited that took off about 25% of the year, HR says it's justified however they had no proof of it.
You might be thinking, well maybe you're just a bad manager? 
No, this is chronic throughout the Arizona Ocotillo campus. All managers suffered with people abusing the time off policies and it was substantially worse during and since Covid.
I had to leave the company. We couldn't get anything done and the output and quality of the work showed.
I did like the company, its vision, and the CEO, however the bureaucracy and policy abuse made me leave. Now I work at a small firm and everyone shows up, everyone does their part, and everyone understands that they must contribute.

review_title: Executive leaders putting the cost decades of poor decisions on lowest folks
job_title: Senior Technical Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The company is large enough that you have a lot of career flexibility and there are incredibly talented people in the execution ranks. Recent roadmap changes has some potential to improve company outlook in the very long term.
cons: As of January 31, 2023, effective immediately, Intel has completely eliminated all merit raises, all RSUs, all bonuses. They’ve also eliminated all performance awards (even simple Kudus, which is as little as $10). And while Intel is not a high compensation company to begin with, executive leadership has also reduced base salaries: 5% for grade 7-10, increased to only a 25% reduction of the CEOs’s base salary. Meanwhile, the CEO’s earnings is essentially all stock, making this of no consequence to him or his senior leaders, even while the HR Exec claims senior leaders are taking their fair share of this burden (I’m paraphrasing). They choose to keep their above average dividends in place making sure they’re making plenty on the stock’s minor improvements from this annihilation of the talent and remaining culture of the company. All of this putting the burden of this ‘righting of the ship’ on the lower staff rather than the leaders responsible for destroying this company’s technological leadership through awful roadmap decisions and so many terrible acquisitions that all cash made in the hay day has been lost with absolutely nothing to show for it. This all while laying off so many people and shipping jobs to “low cost geos”. All this while happily taking federal incentives for massive capital investments. Let’s not kid ourselves either, this layoff and compensation reduction was done because they know the tech industry is imploding making it near impossible for anyone to decide to leave; everyone is basically trapped. IMHO: The roadmap has potential to improve the outlook for this company in the next decade, but I find this senior leadership behavior horrible and a violation of the social contract they have with the employees and the communities that they benefit from. Finally, on top of all of this, even before the layoffs and compensation cuts, I have talked to so many peers who’ve literally said that the culture is gotten so awful and the workload has become so overwhelming that it’s ‘slowly killing us’.

pros: Above average pay. Benefits. Campus is in nice area.
cons: Unlike almost every other tech company, Intel is dragging their feet with layoffs. Instead of the CEO taking ownership he slashed everyone's budget and is passing the buck to lower level managers to make cuts. Problem is now, no one knows what's happening. We keep having all-company meetings where employees are BEGGING for more info and the executive leadership team will only cherry pick questions that make them look good. It will be questions about new problems when almost everyone's concern is whether or not we will have a job next year. The feeling is that our executives are leaving everyone out to dry during the holiday season because they don't want to look bad. The general consensus is that we do not have a strong leader and employees are getting very worried!

cons: Some issues with the culture due to previous CEO Bob Swan's changes to performance review. Bob made it easy to lay off anyone upon short notice, under the guise of reforming the culture. First-line (often inexperienced) managers have full authority to write anything about their subordinates' work into the system/ database, and this affects teamwork, ethics and honesty. The company stock prices keeps hitting all-time low, and unless the current CEO is able to fix all the damages, it's a hard time keeping up with the competition

review_title: Amazing but burned out, fullfilling but exhausting

You get the discussion between different sites, different sectors, departments, modules that will help you a lot in building up your skills
cons: As mentioned, you will often feel burned out and exhausted during work. Depending on where is your department, you will be constantly on the run to keep up with schedule. That's being said, the process of introduction new ideas and get it to the implementation takes very long time, years in my case during some of the projects due to its complexity. You might feel overwhelmed at one point and extremely free at another point due to the nature of manufacturing market.

Some people love their job, some people get treated really well and have good managers.
Good benefits compared to all the companies that have no benefits.

cons:
Some people get brutally overworked and taken advantage of because they're salary.
Some managers are workaholics, bullies, and are not fit for management or leadership roles, but end up there because they're aren't many pathways upward besides management. 
The company is generally exploitative of employee salary status.
Pay is barely competitive (if competitive at all). You can make more instances as a consultant or contractor supporting Intel's projects (though some "green badge" consultant/contractor companies are very exploitative and take advantage of their employees worse than Intel does). You could make the same amount at city, county, or state jobs. You could make the same amount in places with less cost of living than places where Intel does business.
Management seems to change their mind all of the time, which creates a hectic work environment.

pros:
Great experience
Great people
Global teams add great perspective
Opportunity to move throughout the company
cons:
I was told twice in my 4 years by two different managers that I was no longer eligible for promotions because I hadn't been in that grade level long enough. This is not a rule - it's an old school mindset keeping high performers from continuing to perform.
In HR, we work on projects to "solve needs" without listening to the rest of the company. It's disheartening to continually work on projects, get a round of applause from HR, then see it get languish with the actual customers.
Skills of employees is not balanced - due to lack of ability, I was consistently working on "high priority" projects because I was the only one who was able to. Of course, these projects weren't even needed so I burnt out for nothing.
Pay is not competitive when looking externally. 
"Critical" initiatives are supported by a single person with 0 budget. Lots of lip service to these RISE goals but no actual internal investment.
Professional knowledge is not respected if you're lower in hierarchy.

review_title: My Experience at Intel - So Far
pros: Intel has a great work-life balance, has a sabbatical program where you can get between 4-8 weeks off dependent upon time served, bonuses (I didn't list them because the amount is based on earnings, but factors into salary significantly), great health benefits, great on-site benefits, great location, and lots of relative opportunity for growth.
cons: Some of the benefits surrounding education are overstated - for example, I work in a primarily computer-based role, but I have been told it is out of my group's scope to fund CSE degrees including BS or MS programs. Intel likes to proactively move managers into uncomfortable situations to make them stronger - but occasionally, you get stuck with a manager who has no interest in bettering your career. Somewhat political and often times your "reputation precedes you" - I received an informal, off-the-books coaching, and it has lasted two years as a "well remember that one time though?" Despite high performance.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: I work at Intel because it enables me to do what I love, take on some of the toughest challenges in the world. Every problem I work on is huge. Small decisions that I make can make huge differences in the happiness and productivity of hundreds of thousands of employees. There are few places that allow this sort of impact. I am excited to go to work every day. Sure there are the normal challenges, but my actual work, I love it.
cons: If you have wrong manager, your life will be miserable. If you are unhappy with your manager, find a new one as soon as possible. The meeting culture at Intel can be very difficult to work in. There are meetings for everything. I have had jobs where over 75% of my time has been in meetings. I wrote code on the weekend just to get my fix. The jobs in the bureaucracy that require lots of meetings pay well, but they are really boring if you are a person who likes to be a hands on keyboard software engineer.

review_title: Pretty good company to work in
pros: good benefits work life balance

pros: Total compensation is great - if you can get in at a favorable job grade. Annual bonus, quarterly bonus. Equity is a roller coaster, but RSUs unlike options are always worth *something*. Benefits are equal to or better than most companies these days.
cons:
Getting a job grade promotion is not easy or fast. IT is painful, driven by spite rather than employee enablement. Standard monitor and laptop allocation is a trip back to 2002 . Intel is so in bed with Microsoft that they make it difficult to using anything but Microsoft Windows, regardless of whether you need it to do your job effectively. If you need to use things like shells and terminals, your department can buy you a Mac, but IT will not. IT support is offshored, so most people live with broken things rather than sink time trying to get fixes.

Chat is via Teams & actively discouraged. Primary means of communication is, believe it or not, email and meeting after meeting after meeting.

review_title: OTF is where careers go to die
pros: Company benefits are nice but do not under any circumstances accept a position at OTF site in Chandler. They have had a transfer restriction in place for two out of the three years I had worked there, completely torpedoing my career.
cons: These were prime years in my career ascent in my 20s that were nerfed by the blanket transfer block. I interviewed at other sites for positions where I could grow in the company but the transfer block deterred hiring managers from extending an offer and when I did get one I was told 'no'. The  senior managers dont relate and dont care because their queue for their next promotion is years-long and they are already committed to OTF/Arizona at this point in their career so they dont understand how damaging this is to early/mid career people. Accepting a position at this site at Intel was the biggest career mistake I have ever made, while my peers at other companies have been able to grow in their company unrestricted. I and many of my peers consider it unethical, and just plain wrong. Additionally, due to the transfer block people just straight up leave the company (bitter and with no intent of ever coming back) rather than moving to a team or site or position that best suits their skillset. It flies in the face of what broader Intel claims to stand for but seems to go unchallenged.

pros: - Opportunities for growth and career advancement : Intel is a large company with many departments and areas of expertise, providing employees with numerous opportunities for growth and career advancement. - Competitive compensation and benefits : Intel offers competitive compensation packages, including salaries, bonuses, and stock options. The company also provides comprehensive benefits packages that include health insurance, retirement plans, and paid time off. - Innovative work environment : Intel is at the forefront of technological innovation, and employees have the opportunity to work on cutting-edge projects and products. - Global presence: Intel has a global presence, with offices and facilities around the world, providing employees with the opportunity to work on international projects and collaborate with colleagues from diverse backgrounds.
cons: - High-pressure work environment : Intel operates in a highly competitive industry, and employees may experience high-pressure work environments with tight deadlines and demanding workloads. - Limited work-life balance : Intel may require employees to work long hours or be available to work outside of regular business hours, which can impact work-life balance. - Frequent restructuring and changes : As a large company, Intel may undergo frequent restructuring and changes, which can lead to uncertainty and job instability for employees. - Slow decision-making processes : Intel is a large organization, and decision-making processes can be slow, which can be frustrating for employees who need to move quickly to meet project deadlines or other business needs.

pros: - Great bonus system; anyone can give anyone else a bonus, with manager permission. - Top-level talent; so many people to learn from. - Flexible work hours; most people aren't concerned about the hours you work, provided you get the work don.e - Opportunity to work different roles; anyone can apply for a gig (2-20 hours a week) in another team, building out their expertise in that area.
cons: - High expectations. The bar is high and exceeding that often is near impossible. Can make life stressful. - Over-management; lots of schemes and initiatives created by a bored middle-management, that take up lots of time with little return more often than not. - Death by meetings; often feels like I spend more time in meetings than it does doing work. Everyone claims that anyone is free to leave when they feel the meeting isn't provided value, but in reality, you're expected to be and participate in them.

review_title: I would give it a shot
pros: This is a technician level position, so it can be a nice foot in the door for someone just out of school or in possession of an associates degree. Military experience is also accepted for this position. The pay is relatively good. The management and people working here are some of the greatest you'll ever encounter. Great benefits and growth opportunities are there if you really want them.
cons: Culture of "need to know" is confusing to people that function best when they understand how everything works. If you can be told to do a thing and repeat it and you aren't compelled to understand things beyond the scope of your position, this is fine, you'll love it. Feed your family and you are good to go. But if you are inquisitive, this job will be tough. Without the bachelors (if you don't have), they won't pay you much attention. You won't get training beyond what they want you to do and it will really confuse you when you interact with other departments. It compartmentalized in a way that makes it impossible for you to put the pieces together, unless you work here for several decades.

job_title: RD Packaging Engineer in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Very good experience people there than can transfer they knowledge if they want
cons: Intel is too big to be competitive and maintain the market leadership like 10 years ago. Smaller companies who are more specialized in one or two area are eating Intel's lunch. Currently Intel is involved in multiple categories such as foundry, design and assembly/test which is not on top in any of those. TSMC and Samsung chips are better and OSATs do much better jobs in test/assembly. I believe this eventually leads to more downfall.

review_title: Overll Moving in the Right Direction
pros: The engineers are top-notch and very down-to-earth in my experience. Compa ratios increased last year to become more competitive with the rest of the industry. Good benefits package (well-priced insurance, standard retirement plan, some good benefits when buying things from other companies and some fantastic deals on Intel products). Still at the forefront of processor design and innovation. Management seems to be moving in the right direction. Pat's weekly updates feel a lot more transparent than past CEOs. Lot of long-term development and investment plans that could really pay off - an exciting roadmap. If Pat is to be believed, we are at the bottom of a saddle period now, so we will be riding high again in not too long as R&D is completed and investments pay off.
cons: Currently in a contraction. Management overspent during the COVID semiconductor boom and is paying for it now. Job security is a concern during these times. Management could still work a little bit on transparency and listening to feedback. Product development and timelines in the past few years was atrocious, but a lot of changes were implemented that seem to be getting things back on-track.

job_title: Senior Maintenance Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Safety is very important in the culture. Hard to lose your job. Superviors tend to be people oriented. The use of technology to cover a multiple tools spread over a large area is amazing but need to be refined.
cons: Safety is important but if it slows things down, you are accountable for the time lost. This means you have to find a safe way to accomplishs the task at a faster pace safely. Hiring cheap these days, it is find a way to train new tech to have 20 years of experience in 9 months. The numbers of tech are not increasing with the number of fabs. 1.2 miles from one tool to the next and your are manage to the speed at which you travel from one to the other.

pros: Co-workers are great to work with! GSM, HVM sites, other organizations for the most part have good and solid Managers! Organizations within intel (HVM sites, GSM, sales, etc.) are for the most part excellent to work for and with. Intel is a great company for the most part which I have a vast appreciation for!
cons: Other organizations within intel cater far too much to TD organization which contributes to their weak performances and results thus their limited success. Large # of TD Mgmt. are self-absorbed/arrogant and thus rarely listen and follow direction of others. Difficult to work with for the most part although they do have some good Manager's, but they are far and few in-between.

review_title: Good work-life balance, not so good salary and perks
job_title: Cloud Developer in San Jose, CA
pros: The company does innovative work and usually does not require employee to overwork.
cons: Salaries are not very competitive and benefits/perks are pretty basic. Can you believe that they have vending machines for a bag of chips?? Looks like they really need our quarters to be profitable. Compare that with free lunch at Google... In the SJI building they don't even have coffee, but other buildings do. In the bay area a big chunk of the salary is in stocks, but the stock price has been going down for years, so you end up being paid way less than promised when the stocks vest, and the management doesn't seem to care. They even cut the base salaries lately, equally to almost everyone, with no difference for bad and top performers, which is not giving a good signal.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Good health insurance. Between vacation, floating holidays and personal absence time, time off is better than most companies if you are not exempt.
cons: Used to be a great place to work, now, it is just another big tech company whos employees are just numbers. They have widdled the perks down to nothing saying it is industry standard. If you want to have the best talent, shouldn't you offer more than standard? 401k used to be SERP of 12%, did not have to contribute at all, then it was 10, then 8, then 6 to a 401k match of 5% to now the match is dropped to 2%. Just the tip of many other lost incentives

pros: The only reasons that I'm staying right now is for the healthcare benefits and my team members. Currently looking for other employment.
cons: The work that I do is more administrative than engineering. The training is horrible. Information is difficult to get, systems are out dated, tools are out dated, benefits have been cut or taken away, there are people who have been around for 20+ years and refuse to train new people saying that it's a waste of their time. Intel loves to have meetings... just to have meetings! They don't like to see that there is any down time. Intel expects everyone to do the job of more than one person, so everyone is over worked, exhausted, and brain washed. Toxic.

review_title: Avoid the Dry-Etch Department! Experience might differ in other departments.
pros: The health benefits are good.
cons: Manamgnet is horrible. Group Leaders are not appropriately trained. Area managers hide behind the group leaders and provide few solutions for their overworked technicians. They will work you to death, and they prevent Grade Level promotions. You can perform all of your job duties and still not advance. It is not a suitable environment for mental health; you will experience a lot of anxiety trying to please management and engineering.

job_title: Application Engineer in Santa Clara, CA
pros: 1. There are some awesome teams - pick carefully though. 2. Women's networking groups 3. Amazing mentoring ("Find an Expert") 4. Some amazing teammates and ability to form human connections with strangers 5. Definite pockets without gender issues, but pick manager carefully. 6. Suggest women work with witi.com for more info on women working at Intel and to hopefully find the right spot.
cons: 1. Some areas have toxic work environment for women - but certainly not all! 2. Intel has only recently begun to fix pay for women (doubling my friend's base salary), but has done nothing to fix the fact that low pay is compounded by: stock options and bonuses based on base pay, and any % raise is based on low pay. This causes a cumulation of lost $$ much higher than simple base salary comparison. 3. Don't go to HR if you have a problem with a toxic work environment. There is a way to search for/interview for other internal jobs without your boss knowing about it. Switch jobs asap if there is a problem. Because it is most probably not about you, and you can't fix a bad situation. 4. Strongly suggest you maximize base pay (due to cumulative impact) during job negotiations. New California laws also require them to be more transparent about pay so that inequities are more visible. Advocate for yourself without expecting fairness. 5. Like many companies, "corporate values" are simply words without substance.

review_title: Great working environment, an all you can eat buffet of engineering
pros: Students get basically the same type of tasks as full-time employees. It will take a few months to prove your worth and get the management to trust you with significant tasks, but once that's done you will be treated as an equal team member. This allows you to learn a whole lot more than in similar jobs in other companies that only give "dirty work" to students. Additionally, as Intel is an international company you will be in touch with coworkers around the globe which is a great opportunity to improve your English. The fact that you are able to work from home offers much-needed flexibility that allows you to balance work and studies.
cons: The job is quite demanding. There is always more work to be done, and there are often meetings in the evening with coworkers around the globe. This means there is very little separation between "work" and "home". You will likely have to work more than the already demanding 2.5 days you are required by the contract to finish all your tasks on time.

pros: Good work/life balance, good pay and benefits, if you don't like your manager or job there are many opportunities elsewhere within the company and moving every couple years isn't frowned upon (it's considered good development and actually encouraged), highly ethical company, some of the best senior managers in the business. I've traveled around the world many times and taken Stanford/MIT post-grad classes courtesy of Intel. review_title: Executive leaders putting the cost decades of poor decisions on lowest folks
job_title: Senior Technical Program Manager in Hillsboro, OR
pros: The company is large enough that you have a lot of career flexibility and there are incredibly talented people in the execution ranks. Recent roadmap changes has some potential to improve company outlook in the very long term.
cons: As of January 31, 2023, effective immediately, Intel has completely eliminated all merit raises, all RSUs, all bonuses. They’ve also eliminated all performance awards (even simple Kudus, which is as little as $10). And while Intel is not a high compensation company to begin with, executive leadership has also reduced base salaries: 5% for grade 7-10, increased to only a 25% reduction of the CEOs’s base salary. Meanwhile, the CEO’s earnings is essentially all stock, making this of no consequence to him or his senior leaders, even while the HR Exec claims senior leaders are taking their fair share of this burden (I’m paraphrasing). They choose to keep their above average dividends in place making sure they’re making plenty on the stock’s minor improvements from this annihilation of the talent and remaining culture of the company. All of this putting the burden of this ‘righting of the ship’ on the lower staff rather than the leaders responsible for destroying this company’s technological leadership through awful roadmap decisions and so many terrible acquisitions that all cash made in the hay day has been lost with absolutely nothing to show for it. This all while laying off so many people and shipping jobs to “low cost geos”. All this while happily taking federal incentives for massive capital investments. Let’s not kid ourselves either, this layoff and compensation reduction was done because they know the tech industry is imploding making it near impossible for anyone to decide to leave; everyone is basically trapped. IMHO: The roadmap has potential to improve the outlook for this company in the next decade, but I find this senior leadership behavior horrible and a violation of the social contract they have with the employees and the communities that they benefit from. Finally, on top of all of this, even before the layoffs and compensation cuts, I have talked to so many peers who’ve literally said that the culture is gotten so awful and the workload has become so overwhelming that it’s ‘slowly killing us’.

pros: Above average pay. Benefits. Campus is in nice area.
cons: Unlike almost every other tech company, Intel is dragging their feet with layoffs. Instead of the CEO taking ownership he slashed everyone's budget and is passing the buck to lower level managers to make cuts. Problem is now, no one knows what's happening. We keep having all-company meetings where employees are BEGGING for more info and the executive leadership team will only cherry pick questions that make them look good. It will be questions about new problems when almost everyone's concern is whether or not we will have a job next year. The feeling is that our executives are leaving everyone out to dry during the holiday season because they don't want to look bad. The general consensus is that we do not have a strong leader and employees are getting very worried!

pros: Pay is ok if stock is doing well, bonuses are better than average. Sabbatical is a good benefit and can be used in 1 or 2 months increments. People you work with are very smart and diverse.

review_title: Good place to start career, but some issues with the culture & devaluing of work
pros: Good work-life balance and flexibility of schedule and work-from-home arrangements. As long as work gets done, almost no one cares where you work from or what you do. Also, really good tools, flows and infrastructure, and overall, a very big and established company. Great place to start a career.
cons: Some issues with the culture due to previous CEO Bob Swan's changes to performance review. Bob made it easy to lay off anyone upon short notice, under the guise of reforming the culture. First-line (often inexperienced) managers have full authority to write anything about their subordinates' work into the system/ database, and this affects teamwork, ethics and honesty. The company stock prices keeps hitting all-time low, and unless the current CEO is able to fix all the damages, it's a hard time keeping up with the competition

review_title: Amazing but burned out, fullfilling but exhausting

You get the discussion between different sites, different sectors, departments, modules that will help you a lot in building up your skills
cons: As mentioned, you will often feel burned out and exhausted during work. Depending on where is your department, you will be constantly on the run to keep up with schedule. That's being said, the process of introduction new ideas and get it to the implementation takes very long time, years in my case during some of the projects due to its complexity. You might feel overwhelmed at one point and extremely free at another point due to the nature of manufacturing market.

pros:
Great compensation and benefits. In normal times there is visible and tangible reward for your effort and achievements.  Excellent job mobility and flexibility for work and personal circumstances and a real team-oriented 'all in this together' attitude. Plus, there is an indescribable thrill to be working on the bleeding edge of the science, the technology, the process, etc. Intel remains a world-class technology innovator.

The majority, a smaller majority than before (pre 2010 ish), of people there are very very skilled, capable and productive. They are easily able to overcome the statistically necessary under-performers while they have a bad year, or two. It all works out as the teams naturally form a mix of skills and attitudes which complement each other. Over the long-term these mixes are more productive than homogeneous groups of excelling performers.

Famously, the sabbatical benefit is to die for. 8 weeks paid sabbatical, no strings, every 7 years, or 4 weeks every 4 years. Intelites count in 7-year increments. Plan it well, make use of it. DO NOT fritter it away on home improvements.
cons:
It all goes to hell in January & February. The Focal system encourages poor antisocial behaviors as employees compete for finite compensation crumbs which are distributed by a multi-tier rating and ranking system. All the objective behaviors of 10 months are tossed aside for subjective visibility-promoting activities in the critical 2 months with a healthy dose of lies and self-promotion. You are at the mercy of short term whims and transitory fads where the appearance of productivity outweighs the achievement of the whole 12 months. It is brutal. Sometimes you win; sometimes you lose. But nowadays losing carries a terminal prognosis.

All the above is flavored by a new positive discrimination towards underrepresented minorities (URMs) which by executive decree have preference for promotion, transfers, and in some measure the ranking benefits. Non-URMs have an additional hurdle of proving their unique ability to fit a role; URMs can fit anywhere and do not cost a department headcount budget for a period of time. Net-net is that if you are not a URM then hiring, transfer, and benefit opportunities narrow quickly. Already there are pockets of URMs which almost exclusively hire each other and even speak their own language in meetings to exclude employees not of that background.

pros:
Great experience
Great people
Global teams add great perspective
Opportunity to move throughout the company
cons:
I was told twice in my 4 years by two different managers that I was no longer eligible for promotions because I hadn't been in that grade level long enough. This is not a rule - it's an old school mindset keeping high performers from continuing to perform.
In HR, we work on projects to "solve needs" without listening to the rest of the company. It's disheartening to continually work on projects, get a round of applause from HR, then see it get languish with the actual customers.
Skills of employees is not balanced - due to lack of ability, I was consistently working on "high priority" projects because I was the only one who was able to. Of course, these projects weren't even needed so I burnt out for nothing.
Pay is not competitive when looking externally. 
"Critical" initiatives are supported by a single person with 0 budget. Lots of lip service to these RISE goals but no actual internal investment.
Professional knowledge is not respected if you're lower in hierarchy.

review_title: My Experience at Intel - So Far
pros: Intel has a great work-life balance, has a sabbatical program where you can get between 4-8 weeks off dependent upon time served, bonuses (I didn't list them because the amount is based on earnings, but factors into salary significantly), great health benefits, great on-site benefits, great location, and lots of relative opportunity for growth.
cons: Some of the benefits surrounding education are overstated - for example, I work in a primarily computer-based role, but I have been told it is out of my group's scope to fund CSE degrees including BS or MS programs. Intel likes to proactively move managers into uncomfortable situations to make them stronger - but occasionally, you get stuck with a manager who has no interest in bettering your career. Somewhat political and often times your "reputation precedes you" - I received an informal, off-the-books coaching, and it has lasted two years as a "well remember that one time though?" Despite high performance.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Hillsboro, OR
pros: I work at Intel because it enables me to do what I love, take on some of the toughest challenges in the world. Every problem I work on is huge. Small decisions that I make can make huge differences in the happiness and productivity of hundreds of thousands of employees. There are few places that allow this sort of impact. I am excited to go to work every day. Sure there are the normal challenges, but my actual work, I love it.
cons: If you have wrong manager, your life will be miserable. If you are unhappy with your manager, find a new one as soon as possible. The meeting culture at Intel can be very difficult to work in. There are meetings for everything. I have had jobs where over 75% of my time has been in meetings. I wrote code on the weekend just to get my fix. The jobs in the bureaucracy that require lots of meetings pay well, but they are really boring if you are a person who likes to be a hands on keyboard software engineer.

pros: Total compensation is great - if you can get in at a favorable job grade. Annual bonus, quarterly bonus. Equity is a roller coaster, but RSUs unlike options are always worth *something*. Benefits are equal to or better than most companies these days.
cons:
Getting a job grade promotion is not easy or fast. IT is painful, driven by spite rather than employee enablement. Standard monitor and laptop allocation is a trip back to 2002 . Intel is so in bed with Microsoft that they make it difficult to using anything but Microsoft Windows, regardless of whether you need it to do your job effectively. If you need to use things like shells and terminals, your department can buy you a Mac, but IT will not. IT support is offshored, so most people live with broken things rather than sink time trying to get fixes.

Chat is via Teams & actively discouraged. Primary means of communication is, believe it or not, email and meeting after meeting after meeting.

review_title: OTF is where careers go to die
pros: Company benefits are nice but do not under any circumstances accept a position at OTF site in Chandler. They have had a transfer restriction in place for two out of the three years I had worked there, completely torpedoing my career.
cons: These were prime years in my career ascent in my 20s that were nerfed by the blanket transfer block. I interviewed at other sites for positions where I could grow in the company but the transfer block deterred hiring managers from extending an offer and when I did get one I was told 'no'. The  senior managers dont relate and dont care because their queue for their next promotion is years-long and they are already committed to OTF/Arizona at this point in their career so they dont understand how damaging this is to early/mid career people. Accepting a position at this site at Intel was the biggest career mistake I have ever made, while my peers at other companies have been able to grow in their company unrestricted. I and many of my peers consider it unethical, and just plain wrong. Additionally, due to the transfer block people just straight up leave the company (bitter and with no intent of ever coming back) rather than moving to a team or site or position that best suits their skillset. It flies in the face of what broader Intel claims to stand for but seems to go unchallenged.

review_title: Good Company for Software Developers (w/ Caveats)
pros: While Intel has lagged on important trends (mobile, GPU), its core CPU business has been resilient due to the industry transition to cloud. Its senior leadership is now intelligently focused on reestablishing Intel's technology leadership despite fierce competition.
cons: For software developers, Intel's best opportunities are those closest to the silicon (e.g., firmware, drivers, APIs). Higher level opportunities (applications and services) lack the kind of commitment and focus you see with the lower level opportunities due to a lack of business resonance.
